Fig 6 Selective hydrogenation of acetylene over Pd/β-Mo2C catalyst: Experimental and theoretical studies Qinglei Wu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation a 1 Chenyang Shen Visualization Methodology Investigation a b 1 Chang-jun Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Investigation Funding acquisition Data curation Conceptualization a ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 China aSchool of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China b Key Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, China Key Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nanjing University Nanjing 210023 China bKey Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Molybdenum carbide is a promising support to tune the metal reactivity, which originates from the interaction between metal and support. In this work, Pd/β-Mo2C was prepared using a deposition-precipitation method for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. The high temperature calcination is employed to modulate the interaction between Pd and β-Mo2C. The Pd/β-Mo2C catalyst calcined at 600 °C exhibits significant promotion in selective hydrogenation, which shows 100 % acetylene conversion and 81.4 % ethylene selectivity at 160 °C. The activity promotion originates from the enhanced electronic metal-support interaction, which induces a shift of Pd 3d to higher binding energy. Besides, the Pd species become atomically dispersed after calcination. The changes in geometric and electronic structure suppress the formation of Pd hydrides, which consequently inhibits the excessive hydrogenation capacity of Pd. The structure variation also affects the adsorption of ethylene. No strong adsorbed ethylene (di-σ bonded ethylene) can be identified, which is conducive to the improvement of ethylene selectivity. Density functional theoretical (DFT) calculations confirm that Pd on β-Mo2C is positively charged. The desorption energy of C2H4* (0.78 eV) is significantly lower than that of further hydrogenation (1.45 eV), which explains the improved ethylene selectivity of the calcinated catalyst. The present study indicates calcination is an effective method to tune the activity of Pd/β-Mo2C for reactions beyond selective hydrogenation of acetylene. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pd β-Mo2C Selective hydrogenation Acetylene Ethylene Strong metal-support interaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogenation is an important operation in industrial chemical syntheses. Among all the hydrogenation transformations, selective hydrogenation is more attractive and, sometimes, challenging. For example, the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene has been extensively applied for the conversion of trace acetylene in the ethylene production via the steam cracking [1–4]. During the selective hydrogenation process, acetylene is transformed into ethylene, whereas the unsaturated ethylene cannot be further hydrogenated to ethane [5–7]. Therefore, the catalyst of high selectivity with high activity is required. The selective hydrogenation of acetylene is also important for the fundamental understanding of the structure-performance relationship of the catalyst. Because of their high hydrogenation activity, the Pd-based catalysts have been extensively investigated and industrially applied for selective hydrogenation of acetylene [8–10]. However, the pure Pd catalyst alone normally has a strong hydrogenation ability, which causes the over hydrogenation of acetylene. The strong hydrogenation ability of Pd is closely associated with the Pd hydride species. Teschner et al. [11] found that over-hydrogenation occurs on the hydrogen-saturated Pd hydride species. In practice, the partial pressure of hydrogen is an important factor in modulating the activity and selectivity of hydrogenation of acetylene. As the hydrogen pressure increases, a significant increase in acetylene conversion was observed, accompanied by a simultaneous increase in ethane selectivity [12]. Besides, Pd ensembles generally exhibit strong adsorption of ethylene [2], which hinders the desorption of ethylene from the catalyst and promotes the over hydrogenation of acetylene to ethane. In some cases, CO is utilized as a competing adsorbate to suppress the adsorption of hydrogen and ethylene [13,14], which consequently suppresses the further hydrogenation of ethylene. Aside from modifying reaction conditions, the development of more efficient catalysts is the key focus of research worldwide. The most widely applied strategy is introducing a secondary metal to modify the Pd catalysts [15–18]. Among various metals, Pd-Ag alloys are the most widely accepted and applicable catalysts in the industry [19]. Huang et al. [20] reported that the charge transfer from Ag to Pd weakens the adsorption of the unsaturated hydrocarbon, leading to the preference for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. Khan et al. [21] suggested that the addition of Ag suppresses the formation of subsurface hydrogen, which is related to the over-hydrogenation of acetylene. Designing single-atom catalysts is another important method to promote the semi-hydrogenation [22–24]. Tuning the interaction between single-atom Pd and the support (or a secondary metal) can affect the electronic structure of Pd, which finally results in the change in catalytic performance. Au- [25], Ag- [2], and Cu-alloyed [26] Pd single-atom catalysts have exhibited a significantly improved in selectivity. Transition-metal carbides (TMCs), as noble-metal-like materials, have been widely investigated in electrocatalysis [27,28]. They are also promising as support for heterogeneous catalysis. It was reported that β-Mo2C can interact with the metal and modulate the electronic structure at the support-metal interface [29], implying its potential application in selective hydrogenation reaction. However, β-Mo2C supported palladium catalyst has not been studied for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. In this work, we attempted to investigate the β-Mo2C supported Pd catalysts for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. We confirm that the preparation method and the dispersion of palladium catalyst have significant effect on the performance of Pd/β-Mo2C. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation β-Mo2C was synthesized following the method reported in the literature [30]. 1.0 g (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O (HEOWNS, 99 %) was dissolved in 25 mL deionized water at room temperature. 0.5 g melamine (Aladdin, 99 %) was added into 50 mL deionized water and heated until complete dissolution. The hot melamine solution was slowly cooled down to room temperature, resulting in an oversaturated melamine solution. The (NH4)6Mo7O24•4H2O solution was then rapidly added to the oversaturated melamine solution, leading to the formation of a white precipitate. The white precipitate was separated by centrifugation and dehydrated through vacuum freeze-drying overnight. β-Mo2C was obtained by calcinating the white precipitate at 700 °C in the nitrogen atmosphere for 2 h. Pd/β-Mo2C was synthesized by a deposition-precipitation method. 12.5 mg Pd(NO3)2 solution (Aladdin, Pd 18.09 wt. %) and 0.3 g β-Mo2C were mixed in 40 mL deionized water. The obtained mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The Na2CO3 (Macklin, 99 %) solution was then added dropwise to the mixture until the pH reached 9. After that, the mixture was stirred for another 2 h at room temperature. The solid was separated from the mixture by centrifugation and washed with deionized water. The black solid was dehydrated through vacuum freeze-drying overnight. The dried solid was calcinated at 600 °C in the argon atmosphere for 1 h and then reduced by flowing hydrogen. The resulting catalyst was labeled as Pd/β-Mo2C-600. The calcination temperature of 600 °C was decided by the experimental study of the effect of calcination temperature. From this study, the optimum calcination temperature was found to be 600 °C. As a comparison, the solid only reduced by flowing hydrogen was denoted as Pd/β-Mo2C. 2.2 Characterization of the catalyst Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 5110, USA) was conducted to investigate the element content of Pd/β-Mo2C-600 and Pd/β-Mo2C. The measurement of N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm was carried out at 77 K using an Autosorb-1-C (Quantachrome) analyzer. The Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method was employed to calculate the specific surface area. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were collected by a Rigaku Smartlab diffractometer. The scan angle 2θ was ranged from 20° to 80° with a scanning rate of 4° min-1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and dark-filed scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images were collected by a JEOL JEM-F200 system. The element distribution was investigated by the energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mappings. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained through an aberration-corrected FEI Titan G2 60–300 system. A thermo ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer, with Al Kα (hv = 1486.6 eV) as the excitation source, was employed to conduct the in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses. The XPS spectra of Pd/β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 were collected after reduction by flowing hydrogen. Subsequently, the catalyst was treated in the reaction condition at 160 °C and the XPS spectra were then collected. The spectra obtained were calibrated by the C 1s peak (284.8 eV). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed with a Quantachrome ChemBET Pulsar chemisorption analyzer. 50 mg sample was purged with argon at 200 °C for 1 h to remove the impurities. The sample was then cooled down to 25 °C. The gas was switched to 10 % H2 in argon. H2-TPR was conducted from 25 °C to 450 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The effluent was analyzed by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature-programmed hydride decomposition (TPHD) was performed using the way reported in the literature [31] on the Quantachrome ChemBET Pulsar chemisorption analyzer. The sample was firstly reduced by flowing hydrogen at 200 °C. The reduced catalyst was cooled down to 25 °C and purged with the gas of 10 % H2 in argon for 1 h. TPHD was performed from 25 °C to 125 °C in the flowing hydrogen. C2H2 temperature-programmed desorption (C2H2-TPD) was performed on the Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. The sample was firstly reduced in hydrogen at 200 °C. Then the sample was purged with helium and cooled down to room temperature. The sample was exposed to the gas of C2H2 for 1 h. After that, the sample was purged with helium to remove the physically adsorbed C2H2. Finally, the C2H2-TPD was performed from −50 °C to 500 °C. C2H4 temperature-programmed desorption (C2H4-TPD) profiles were collected with the same method. 2.3 Catalytic performance The selective hydrogenation of acetylene was performed in a fixed-bed reactor. 50 mg catalyst and 200 mg SiC were homogeneously mixed and loaded in a quartz tube. Before the activity test, the supported Pd catalysts were pretreated in flowing hydrogen (10 % H2 in N2) at 200 °C for 1 h. Then the reaction was conducted in the feed gas (C2H2:H2:Ar = 1:10:89) from 60 °C to 200 °C at 1 atm. The flow rate of the feed gas was 50 mL min-1 with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60, 000 mL gcat -1 h-1. An online gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 4890) was connected to the reactor. The effluent of the reactor was analyzed by a flame ionization detector (FID). Ethylene and ethane, identified by the FID, are the gaseous products of the reaction. The conversion of acetylene ( X a c e t y l e n e ), the selectivity of ethylene ( S e t h y l e n e ), and the selectivity of ethane ( S e t h a n e ) are calculated by the following equations: X a c e t y l e n e = F C 2 H 2 , i n − F C 2 H 2 , o u t F C 2 H 2 , i n × 100 % S e t h y l e n e = F C 2 H 4 , o u t F C 2 H 2 , i n − F C 2 H 2 , o u t × 100 % S e t h a n e = F C 2 H 6 , o u t F C 2 H 2 , i n − F C 2 H 2 , o u t × 100 % S oligomer = 1 − S e t h y l e n e − S e t h a n e where F is the molar flow rate. 2.4 Computational methods and models The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP 5.4.4) [32,33] code. The exchange and correlation energies were described with the generalized gradient approximation in the form of Perdew−Burker−Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) functional [34]. Core electrons were represented by projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials [35], while the valence electrons were expanded from a plane-wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV. A Monkhorst-Pack (3 × 3 × 1) k-point grid was employed for the sampling of the Brillouin zone. The reaction energy and energy barrier were defined as the energy difference between the initial state and final state, and the energy difference between the initial state and transition state, respectively. All the transition states were located via the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) [36] and improved dimer method (IDM) [37]. Atomic charges were obtained via the Bader charge analysis [38]. The ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were performed at 160 °C. The employed NVT ensemble was set with a time step of 1 fs using a Nosé-Hoover thermostat for a period of 10 ps. The Pd(111) surface (Figure S1) was modeled by a p(4 × 4) supercell with four atomic layers, and the top two layers were allowed to relax. The β-Mo2C(101) surface was modeled by a 4-layered p(2 × 4) supercell consisting of 64 molybdenum and 32 carbon atoms, of which 32 molybdenum and 16 carbon atoms were frozen in their bulk lattice positions. A vacuum region of 12 Å was set between each slab to eliminate any periodic interactions along the Z-axial direction. During the structural optimization, all atoms in the bottom two layers were frozen while the other atoms were fully relaxed. On the basis of the palladium contents and structural characterizations, two distinct models were constructed by placing one isolated palladium atom and a 13-atom palladium cluster on the β-Mo2C(101) surface, which are labeled as Pd1-β-Mo2C(101) and Pd13-β-Mo2C(101), respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity The activity of the β-Mo2C support was firstly tested. As shown in Figure S2, β-Mo2C shows a very limited ability in acetylene conversion, which is lower than 1 % below 80 °C. With the increasing temperature, the acetylene conversion slowly increases to 16.5 % at 200 °C, while the ethylene selectivity increases from 64.1 % to 77.7 %. The result confirms that β-Mo2C has the potential for selective hydrogenation [39], but with limited activity. As for Pd/β-Mo2C, acetylene can be completely converted in the temperature range between 60 °C and 200 °C. Pd/β-Mo2C exhibits a strong ability in hydrogenation, resulting in the excessive hydrogenation of acetylene, as shown in Fig. 1a . Ethane is the main product for Pd/β-Mo2C. The ethylene selectivity is only 0.5 % at 60 °C. It increases to 13.4 % at 200 °C. The gradual increase in ethylene selectivity of Pd/β-Mo2C is similar to that observed for β-Mo2C. As shown in Fig. 1b, Pd/β-Mo2C-600 shows a decrease in the acetylene conversion, which reaches 100 % at 160 °C. However, the ethylene selectivity over Pd/β-Mo2C-600 is significantly improved. The ethylene selectivity is 91 % at 60 °C. As the reaction temperature increases, the ethylene selectivity slowly decreases to ca. 80 %. After that, it keeps stable. An activity comparison of Pd/β-Mo2C-600 with the reported Pd-based catalysts is listed in Table S1. From this table, it can be found that the activity of Pd/β-Mo2C-600 is beyond the average. A 40-hour stability test was conducted at the reaction conditions of 160 °C, 1 atm, and GHSV = 60,000 mL gcat -1 h-1. As shown in Fig. 1c, the Pd/β-Mo2C-600 exhibits very stable performance. The acetylene conversion keeps 100 % throughout the test while the ethylene selectivity has a small fluctuation around 81.4 %. The ethane selectivity and oligomer selectivity are finally stable at around 8.1 % and 10.3 %. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The element composition of Pd/β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 is determined by ICP-OES. The content of Mo in Pd/β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 is 93.40 % and 93.63 %, respectively, which is close to the nominal content (93.40 %). The content of Pd in Pd/β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 is 0.61 % and 0.58 %. The BET surface area of β-Mo2C, Pd/β-Mo2C, and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 is 13.85, 15.77, and 9.86 m2 g-1, respectively. The powder XRD patterns of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2a . The unreduced catalysts are denoted as Pd/β-Mo2C-UR and Pd/β-Mo2C-600-UR, while the used catalysts are denoted as Pd/β-Mo2C-AR and Pd/β-Mo2C-600-AR. The diffraction peaks located at 32.5°, 37.8°, 39.5°, 52.2°, 61.9°, 69.5°, 74.9°, and 76.0° belong to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), (112) and (201) facets of β-Mo2C (PDF # 65–8766). The diffraction peaks of Pd cannot be distinguished, suggesting that the Pd species are highly dispersed on β-Mo2C. Besides, there is no diffraction peak around 25° [30,40], indicating MoO3 and graphite carbon species are not introduced as impurities. β-Mo2C shows no weight loss in the thermogravimetric test (Figure S3), which also confirms that there is no carbon species residue in the catalysts. The ACHADDF-STEM image of Pd/β-Mo2C-600 is shown in Fig. 2b. The lattice spacing of the support is 0.230 nm, corresponding to the (101) facet of β-Mo2C. Moreover, it is worth noting that Pd clusters present on β-Mo2C (marked by the green circles). As the EDX element mappings of Pd/β-Mo2C-600 show (Fig. 2d), the Pd species is well-dispersed on the β-Mo2C. As for Pd/β-Mo2C, some small dark nanoparticles can be observed (Fig. 2c). EDX element mappings were recorded to further verify the dispersion state of Pd. As shown in Fig. 2e, although most of the Pd species are evenly dispersed, the Pd nanoparticle can be observed simultaneously (marked by the green circles). After the reaction, the used Pd/β-Mo2C-600 also shows well-dispersed Pd species (Figure S4), indicating the Pd species are stable on the β-Mo2C support after a prolonged reaction. The stable Pd species suggests the existence of interaction between Pd and β-Mo2C, which keeps Pd stable in the reaction conditions. Pd/β-Mo2C shows the similar morphology after reaction, in which Pd nanoparticles can be still found (Figure S5). To investigate the chemical state variation of surface elements in the reduction and reaction conditions, in situ XPS tests were conducted over Pd/β-Mo2C-600 and Pd/β-Mo2C. The Pd 3d core level spectra of the catalysts treated in the reduction atmosphere are shown in Fig. 3a . For Pd/β-Mo2C, the binding energy of 335.2 eV belongs to the Pd0 3d5/2, suggesting Pd is in the metallic state [41]. Different from Pd/β-Mo2C, Pd 3d5/2 of Pd/β-Mo2C-600 shows a 0.4 eV offset towards the direction of higher binding energy. This suggests the existence of the strong electronic interaction between Pd and β-Mo2C, which consequently induces the electron transfer from Pd to β-Mo2C. After being treated in the reaction conditions, the Pd 3d binding energy of both catalysts remains almost unchanged (Figure S6). The Pd 3d spectra demonstrate that the high-temperature calcination can induce the strong interaction between Pd and β-Mo2C. Such strong interaction is not observed in the catalyst without the calcination. As shown in Fig. 3b and 3c, the Mo 3d spectra are carefully deconvoluted according to the method reported in the literature [42]. Three sets of doublets can be attributed to the Mo2+ of β-Mo2C. The dominant peak of Mo2+ features Mo 3d5/2 centered at 228.0 eV, while the other two are centered at 228.7 eV and 231.7 eV. Despite measures have been taken, the surface of β-Mo2C is still inevitably partially oxidized when exposed to air. Mo4+, Mo5+, and Mo6+ species appear as the result of oxidation. Mo4+ has two sets of doublets with Mo 3d5/2 centered at 229.2 eV and 230.4 eV while the 3d5/2 of Mo5+ and Mo6+ are centered at 231.3 eV and 232.5 eV. For Pd/β-Mo2C-600, the pristine catalyst exhibits pronounced surface oxidation. Calculated by the areas of the peaks, the proportion of Mo2+ is 39.8 % in pristine Pd/β-Mo2C-600. After being treated in reduction and reaction conditions, the amount of Mo2+ increases to 62.5 % and 66.6 %. The increase of Mo2+ species suggests that the oxidized Mo species of β-Mo2C can be reduced in the reducing atmosphere. Compared with Pd/β-Mo2C-600, the pristine Pd/β-Mo2C has more oxidized species and less Mo2+ (30.5 %). After being treated in the reduction and reaction atmosphere, the Mo species show a similar change trend to that of Pd/β-Mo2C-600. However, the proportion of Mo2+ species in Pd/β-Mo2C is lower compared to that of Pd/β-Mo2C-600 under identical conditions (Table S2). This indicates that the calcination at 600 °C is conducive to removing the surface oxidized species of β-Mo2C. Besides, the C 1s spectra of Pd/β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 (Figure S7) also illustrate the oxidized species decrease in the reducing atmosphere. The H2-TPR profiles of β-Mo2C, Pd/β-Mo2C, and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 are shown in Fig. 4a . The catalysts all have a hydrogen consumption peak below 300 °C (denoted as peak Ⅰ) while β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C have an additional peak around 350 °C (denoted as peak Ⅱ). According to the changing trend of oxidized species of β-Mo2C in the reducing atmosphere recorded by the XPS spectra, these hydrogen consumption peaks are attributed to the reduction of surface oxidized species. Compared to the peak Ⅰ of β-Mo2C, the peak Ⅰ of Pd/β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 shifts to lower temperatures, suggesting that the presence of Pd is conducive to the reduction process. Furthermore, the hydrogen consumption of Pd/β-Mo2C-600 is significantly less than Pd/β-Mo2C, indicating Pd/β-Mo2C-600 has less oxidized species. This result is consistent with the Mo 3d spectra of the pristine Pd/β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C-600. No reduction peak of Pd species can be observed, implying Pd can be reduced at lower temperatures [43]. However, Pd/β-Mo2C shows a small negative peak below 100 °C, which might be the decomposition of Pd hydride. Therefore, temperature-programmed hydride decomposition (TPHD) was performed with β-Mo2C, Pd/β-Mo2C, and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 (Fig. 4b). β-Mo2C is poor in hydrogen activation [44]. There is no signal of hydride decomposition. For Pd/β-Mo2C, there is a peak centered at 77 °C, which corresponds to the decomposition of Pd hydride [45]. However, Pd hydride decomposition is not observed on Pd/β-Mo2C-600. According to the literature [31,46], Pd hydride can be easily formed on Pd ensembles with large sizes. However, it is suppressed on the atomically dispersed Pd. As a result, the Pd nanoparticle promotes the formation of Pd hydride on Pd/β-Mo2C in the hydrogen atmosphere, whereas Pd hydride can hardly exist on the atomically dispersed Pd on Pd/β-Mo2C-600. Pd hydride is generally accepted as a kind of active hydrogenation species [11,47]. Therefore, the reduction of the oxidized species of Pd/β-Mo2C in the H2-TPR test occurs at a lower temperature compared to that of Pd/β-Mo2C-600. Pd hydride is also active in acetylene hydrogenation, which can result in excessive hydrogenation of acetylene to ethane. Pd/β-Mo2C-600 thus can avoid the strong hydrogenation ability of Pd ensembles and be beneficial to the selective hydrogenation of acetylene. Fig. 5a shows the C2H2-TPD profiles. There are mainly two types of adsorbed acetylene on the catalysts: weakly adsorbed (around 0 °C) and strongly adsorbed acetylene (around 300 °C). Compared to β-Mo2C, the amount and strength of acetylene adsorbed on Pd/β-Mo2C increase. The desorption temperature of weakly adsorbed and strongly adsorbed acetylene increases from −15 °C and 296 °C to 14 °C and 317 °C. However, after calcination, the desorption temperature of weakly adsorbed acetylene shifts to a lower temperature on Pd/β-Mo2C-600, while the amount of strongly adsorbed acetylene decreases significantly. This indicates that the strong electronic interaction between atomically dispersed Pd and β-Mo2C weakens the adsorption of acetylene. The C2H4-TPD was performed to investigate the ethylene adsorption of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5b, there are mainly two different types of adsorption of ethylene. One is di-σ-bonded. The other is π-bonded ethylene [48,49]. For β-Mo2C, there is only a π-bonded ethylene desorption peak at 11 °C. Pd/β-Mo2C-600 shows a much stronger π-bonded ethylene desorption peak. This is induced by the atomically dispersed Pd, which provides more sites for ethylene adsorption. Both β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C-600 show almost no adsorption of di-σ-bonded ethylene. This indicates that ethylene can easily desorb on β-Mo2C and Pd/β-Mo2C-600, thus contributing to the improvement of ethylene selectivity. However, the π-bonded ethylene has two desorption peaks on Pd/β-Mo2C at 11 °C and 49 °C. The peak located at 11 °C is caused by the adsorption of ethylene on β-Mo2C, while the peak at 49 °C is very likely caused by Pd. Besides, Pd/β-Mo2C has a di-σ-bonded ethylene desorption peak at 320 °C. The appearance of di-σ-bonded ethylene means that ethylene can be adsorbed more strongly on Pd/β-Mo2C. The strong adsorption of ethylene consequently results in the further hydrogenation of ethylene to ethane. It explains the origin of the poor ethylene selectivity of Pd/β-Mo2C. 3.3 DFT calculations Here, DFT calculations were carried out to illustrate the reason why the palladium single atom catalyst exhibits better catalytic performance than the palladium nanoparticle. As depicted in Fig. 6a , two different Mo2C-supported palladium models, i.e., Pd1-β-Mo2C(101) and Pd13-β-Mo2C(101), were thus constructed to mimic the Pd single atom and Pd nanoparticle catalysts. As shown in Figure S8, Pd1-β-Mo2C(101) and Pd13-β-Mo2C(101) present two distinct types of electron transfer. Besides, based on the Bader charge analysis (Figure S9), the isolated palladium atom in Pd1-β-Mo2C(101) is positively charged with +0.53 |e|. However, most surface palladium atoms in Pd13-β-Mo2C(101) exhibit the metallic property. This is in consistent with the projected density of state (PDOS) of palladium (Fig. 6b), where an upward shift of the d band center of the Pd13 cluster with respect to the Fermi level is clearly observed. Taking the local density of state (LDOS) of the selected palladium atom on the surface of bare Pd(111) as a reference, the shift is even more obvious (Figure S10). On the basis of the d-band theory [50], the anti-bonding orbits are less filled for palladium in Pd13-β-Mo2C(101), which might lead to stronger adsorption of acetylene. This is further confirmed by the energy profiles for acetylene hydrogenation, as shown in Fig. 6c and d. With regard to the Pd1-β-Mo2C(101) surface, the adsorption energy of acetylene is −0.89 eV, which is remarkably weaker than that on the Pd13-β-Mo2C(101) surface (−2.56 eV). Meanwhile, the energy barrier for the further hydrogenation of C2H4* is 1.45 eV, which was much higher than the energy required for the desorption of C2H4* from the surface (0.78 eV). As a result, the desorption of ethylene is more preferential during the whole hydrogenation process. In contrast, it is totally different for the Pd13-β-Mo2C(101) surface. Compared to further hydrogenation (Ea=0.61 eV), the desorption of C2H4* (ΔE = 1.02 eV) seems to be more difficult. Above results indicate that the Pd single atom catalyst can effectively inhibit the over-hydrogenation of acetylene on the β-Mo2C surface, leading to the higher selectivity of ethylene, which is in consistent with the experimental results discussed above (Fig. 1). All the reaction intermediates involved in the reaction are presented in Fig. 6e and f, and the corresponding configurations of initial, transition, and final states are shown in Figures S11 and S12. Specially, the structural stability of Pd1-β-Mo2C(101) is also verified by the AIMD results (Figure S13). 4 Conclusion In this work, Pd/β-Mo2C was prepared by a simple deposition-precipitation method. After the 600 °C calcination in the Ar atmosphere, the obtained catalyst (Pd/β-Mo2C-600) shows a significant improvement in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. The Pd/β-Mo2C-600 reaches the 100 % conversion of acetylene at 160 °C with the ethylene selectivity of 81.4 %. TEM images demonstrate that Pd species is atomically dispersed on the β-Mo2C after the calcination. Besides, the 600 °C calcination also facilitates the removal of the surface oxygen species on the β-Mo2C, which simultaneously enhances the interaction between Pd and β-Mo2C. Because of the atomically dispersed Pd and the strong support-metal interaction, the formation of Pd hydrides is completely suppressed on Pd/β-Mo2C-600, which weakens the strong hydrogenation capacity of Pd. Meanwhile, there is almost no di-σ-bonded ethylene adsorbed on the Pd/β-Mo2C-600 catalyst, which greatly contributes to the ethylene desorption and the promotion of ethylene selectivity. DFT calculations confirm the interaction between the Pd single atom and β-Mo2C, which makes Pd in positively charged. The calculated stepwise hydrogenation process of acetylene shows that the energy barrier for further hydrogenation of C2H4* (1.45 eV) is significantly higher than the desorption of C2H4* (0.78 eV), indicating C2H4 prefers desorption rather than further hydrogenation over Pd1-β-Mo2C. coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum carbide is a promising support to tune the metal reactivity, which originates from the interaction between metal and support. In this work, Pd/β-Mo2C was prepared using a deposition-precipitation method for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. The high temperature calcination is employed to modulate the interaction between Pd and β-Mo2C. The Pd/β-Mo2C catalyst calcined at 600 °C exhibits significant promotion in selective hydrogenation, which shows 100 % acetylene conversion and 81.4 % ethylene selectivity at 160 °C. The activity promotion originates from the enhanced electronic metal-support interaction, which induces a shift of Pd 3d to higher binding energy. Besides, the Pd species become atomically dispersed after calcination. The changes in geometric and electronic structure suppress the formation of Pd hydrides, which consequently inhibits the excessive hydrogenation capacity of Pd. The structure variation also affects the adsorption of ethylene. No strong adsorbed ethylene (di-σ bonded ethylene) can be identified, which is conducive to the improvement of ethylene selectivity. Density functional theoretical (DFT) calculations confirm that Pd on β-Mo2C is positively charged. The desorption energy of C2H4* (0.78 eV) is significantly lower than that of further hydrogenation (1.45 eV), which explains the improved ethylene selectivity of the calcinated catalyst. The present study indicates calcination is an effective method to tune the activity of Pd/β-Mo2C for reactions beyond selective hydrogenation of acetylene.
